body:
It makes sense to me that spatial dimensions are dimensions, and if you include them, you don't get the dimensionless behavior.

That being said I think we will need some mode like "I want this core set of dimensions but I want everything else to be ingested too". So like a partially specified schema. This is useful for a bunch of cases:
- Specify spatial dimensions but have the rest be automatic
- Specify some fields as long dimensions but have other fields become string dimensions automatically
- Specify some dimensions so we can set a particular dimension sort order, but leave the rest out

I think this could all be satisfied with some flag like "discoverDimensions" that, if true, would enable dimension discovery even if the user has provided some dimensions and dimension exclusions already. For legacy reasons it should default to "true" if dimensions is null/empty and "false" otherwise. But if explicitly provided it should be respected.
@akashdw you don't need to force push the branch anymore, git will do all the rebasing for us now.

If a particular task fails to launch on a mesos agent too many times, spark can decline future offers from that agent, so be aware of that.

There are a lot of tuning parameters, most notably executor memory and maximum cores, that affect the resources that will be acquired. Also note that spark 2.0 changes how it does resource allocation in Mesos to be much more in line with how the stand-alone cluster functions. I highly recommend getting a migration plan to 2.0 if you haven't started already.

But please check the mesos master's task history first to see if there are failed tasks for that framework.
Practically this change looks good for me, theoretically it introduces a race condition between `delete()` and `schedule()`, but to exploit this race UUID should collide :)

For anyone who found this issue because of an error like `Failed to create directory within 10000 attempts (tried 1477086112673-0 to 1477086112673-9999)`: the problem is possibly that in your jvm.config files, `java.io.tmpdir` is set to a directory that doesn't exist. Creating this directory fixed the problem for me.

Hi, I would like to take this ticket, and am wondering the back-off strategy means any exact implementation of a back-off strategy algorithm.

I believe that this proposal is to make the nodes which are frequently disconnected from the cluster have the lower priority for leader election. One possible solution is to provide an executor service to the leader selector which is capable of backing off participating leader election for the given amount of time. 

Meanwhile, the leader latch provides a kind of back-off strategy inherently. With the leader latch, a leader is elected by the order of written ZK paths. That is, the node which wrote its name first becomes the leader. Thus, since a node rewrites its name whenever it is restored from disconnection, it will have the lowest priority.

I think that the second approach will work well even though there is only one overlord node in a cluster. What do you think?
LGTM

@nishantmonu51 want to review the 2nd commit?
@dclim any benchmarks on how much faster this is?

@fjy regarding benchmarks, the performance improvement is highly dependent on the number of intervals/partitions generated. Here's some data from some of my tests:

Ingesting 6M rows of TPCH in 10 shards:
- Old index task: 11 minutes
- New index task: 7 minutes

Ingesting 6M rows of TPCH in 84 shards:
- Old index task: 53 minutes
- New index task: 13 minutes

Ingesting 30M rows of TPCH in ~50 shards:
- Old index task: 101 minutes
- New index task: 41 minutes
I believe there is still a bug related to topN queries and the Comparator returned by the SketchAggFactory.

looks good to me. üëç

Hi, S3 timeouts are currently giving us major headaches trying to run backfills under 0.9.1.1. We basically cannot scale up our indexing capacity effectively because of this issue.

What would be the prospect of applying this PR onto 0.9.1.1 if we wanted to try it out in a private build? Does it depend on other post 0.9.1.1 changes? Perhaps just teasing out the ReplayableFirehose stuff since that looks like the main part that would help us?
@ryryguy the index task is not recommended for batch ingestion of files greater than 1GB. You should be using hadoop based batch indexing. See https://imply.io/docs/latest/ingestion-batch

@fjy our source files are basically right around 1GB. Some are over (up to 1.6 GB), some are under (down to 500 MB). I'm not sure if the S3 timeouts are correlated to ingestion file size - maybe somewhat, but when we experience periods where the failure rate approaches 100%, that is definitely including files that are well under 1GB.

We briefly took a shot at setting up hadoop based batch indexing and couldn't get it to work. (We have basically zero experience with hadoop on our team...) Since it also reads files from S3, we weren't sure it would really address the problem. But if you think it might help, we can take another shot at it.
@ryryguy The hadoop index task does have automatic retries, at least.

@ryryguy I believe it should be possible to patch this onto 0.9.1.1, keeping the following in mind:
- You'll also need to patch #3483 to fix a cache NPE issue
- #3585 migrated java-util into the Druid repo so you'll need to change some imports from `io.druid.java.util.common.` back to `com.metamx.common.`

That's all I can think of right now but I may have missed something. Use at your own risk :)

as @fjy mentioned, the recommendation for most use cases is using a Hadoop cluster for batch ingestion since it will scale and process files in parallel whereas the index task will not. The Hadoop framework retries failed tasks so that should help with transient S3 issues.

@loganto you have no worker nodes, you'll need to run some middle managers and make sure that they are configured properly so they can be discovered through ZK

In the future, please post your questions to the Druid user group here: https://groups.google.com/forum/?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer#!forum/druid-user
@loganto Set 'druid.server.http.numThreads' to a value of 6 or greater, see https://groups.google.com/forum/?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer#!topic/druid-user/Mbun8csd7xM

@misslzyan there's a Google Group for these types of questions, could you repost your question there? https://groups.google.com/forum/?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer#!forum/druid-user

If your raw input data has duplicates, you'll need to de-dupe them yourself before sending the data to Druid. If you're getting duplicates as part of the ingestion process, you may want to look into the Kafka indexing service which guarantees exactly-once ingestion: http://druid.io/docs/0.9.1.1/development/extensions-core/kafka-ingestion.html

@drcrallen I've also added a follow up change to https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3597: this place: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/commit/78159d7ca442cf8d99ea356d39932ab3adb8e10f#diff-52b91ace82cc677af64b49ff0b736baaR381 looks dangerous, what happens if we failed to CAS the version? Just log.wtf and continue (including swapping the cache) as nothing happened? So I've changed this so that `latestVersion` is updated in the same `synchronized {}` block with `swapAndClearCache()`: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3609/commits/05da84c804bb83905b350145fa26cc57afdb163e

great feature!
@sirpkt, how can I specify the week granularity that starts from Sunday ?
üëç
@fjy backport pr https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3621
üëç

@bkyryliuk 
`week` starts from Monday as it is default of Period Granularity.
You can make query granularity of week that starts from Sunday by using
custom Period Granularity like
`{"type":"period", "period":"P1W","origin":"2016-01-03T00:00:00"}`
`origin` can be any Sunday.

More details in Period Granularity of http://druid.io/docs/latest/querying/granularities.html.
@drcrallen could you please review the changes?
